com.azure.storage.file

Class DirectoryClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.azure.storage.file.DirectoryClient

  • public class DirectoryClient
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides a client that contains all the operations for interacting with directory in Azure Storage File Service. Operations allowed by the client are creating, deleting and listing subdirectory and file, retrieving properties, , setting metadata and list or force close handles of the directory or file.

    Instantiating an Synchronous Directory Client

    DirectoryClient client = new DirectoryClientBuilder()
    .connectionString("${connectionString}")
    .endpoint("${endpoint}")
    .buildClient();

    View this for additional ways to construct the client.

    See Also:
    DirectoryClientBuilder, DirectoryClient, SharedKeyCredential, SASTokenCredential

        public java.net.URL getDirectoryUrl()
        Get the url of the storage directory client.
        Returns:
        the URL of the storage directory client.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the directory is using a malformed URL.

      • getFileClient

        public FileClient getFileClient(java.lang.String fileName)
        Constructs a FileClient that interacts with the specified file.

        If the file doesn't exist in this directory FileClient.create(long) create} in the client will need to be called before interaction with the file can happen.

        Parameters:
        fileName - Name of the file
        Returns:
        a FileClient that interacts with the specified share

      • getSubDirectoryClient

        public DirectoryClient getSubDirectoryClient(java.lang.String subDirectoryName)
        Constructs a DirectoryClient that interacts with the specified directory.

        If the file doesn't exist in this directory DirectoryClient.create() create} in the client will need to be called before interaction with the directory can happen.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        a DirectoryClient that interacts with the specified directory

      • create

        public Response<DirectoryInfo> create()
        Creates a directory in the file share and returns a response of DirectoryInfo to interact with it.

        Code Samples

        Create the directory

        Response<DirectoryInfo> response = directoryClient.create();
System.out.println("Complete creating the directory with status code: " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Returns:
        A response containing the directory info and the status of creating the directory.
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the directory has already existed, the parent directory does not exist or directory name is an invalid resource name.

      • create

        public Response<DirectoryInfo> create(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> metadata)
        Creates a directory in the file share and returns a response of DirectoryInfo to interact with it.

        Code Samples

        Create the directory

        Response<DirectoryInfo> response = directoryClient.create(Collections.singletonMap("directory", "metadata"));
System.out.println("Complete creating the directory with status code: " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        metadata - Optional metadata to associate with the directory.
        Returns:
        A response containing the directory info and the status of creating the directory.
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the directory has already existed, the parent directory does not exist or directory name is an invalid resource name.

      • delete

        public VoidResponse delete()
        Deletes the directory in the file share. The directory must be empty before it can be deleted.

        Code Samples

        Delete the directory

        VoidResponse response = directoryClient.delete();
System.out.println("Complete deleting the file with status code: " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Returns:
        A response that only contains headers and response status code
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the share doesn't exist

      • getProperties

        public Response<DirectoryProperties> getProperties()
        Retrieves the properties of this directory. The properties includes directory metadata, last modified date, is server encrypted, and eTag.

        Code Samples

        Retrieve directory properties

        Response<DirectoryProperties> response = directoryClient.getProperties();
System.out.printf("Directory latest modified date is %s.", response.value().lastModified());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Returns:
        Storage directory properties

      • setMetadata

        public Response<DirectorySetMetadataInfo> setMetadata(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> metadata)
        Sets the user-defined metadata to associate to the directory.

        If null is passed for the metadata it will clear the metadata associated to the directory.

        Code Samples

        Set the metadata to "directory:updatedMetadata"

        Response<DirectorySetMetadataInfo> response =
    directoryClient.setMetadata(Collections.singletonMap("directory", "updatedMetadata"));
System.out.printf("Setting the directory metadata completed with status code %d", response.statusCode());

        Clear the metadata of the directory

        Response<DirectorySetMetadataInfo> response = directoryClient.setMetadata(null);
System.out.printf("Directory latest modified date is %s.", response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        metadata - Optional metadata to set on the directory, if null is passed the metadata for the directory is cleared
        Returns:
        information about the directory
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the directory doesn't exist or the metadata contains invalid keys

      • listFilesAndDirectories

        public java.lang.Iterable<FileRef> listFilesAndDirectories()
        Lists all sub-directories and files in this directory without their prefix or maxResult.

        Code Samples

        List all sub-directories and files in the account

        directoryClient.listFilesAndDirectories().forEach(
    fileRef -> System.out.printf("Is the resource a directory? %b. The resource name is: %s.",
        fileRef.isDirectory(), fileRef.name())
);

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Returns:
        File info in the storage directory

      • listFilesAndDirectories

        public java.lang.Iterable<FileRef> listFilesAndDirectories(java.lang.String prefix,
                                                           java.lang.Integer maxResults)
        Lists all sub-directories and files in this directory with their prefix or snapshots.

        Code Samples

        List all sub-directories and files in this directory with "subdir" prefix and return 10 results in the account

        directoryClient.listFilesAndDirectories("subdir", 10).forEach(
    fileRef -> System.out.printf("Is the resource a directory? %b. The resource name is: %s.",
        fileRef.isDirectory(), fileRef.name())
);

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        prefix - Optional prefix which filters the results to return only files and directories whose name begins with.
        maxResults - Optional maximum number of files and/or directories to return per page. If the request does not specify maxresults or specifies a value greater than 5,000, the server will return up to 5,000 items.
        Returns:
        File info in this directory with prefix and max number of return results.

      • getHandles

        public java.lang.Iterable<HandleItem> getHandles(java.lang.Integer maxResult,
                                                 boolean recursive)
        List of open handles on a directory or a file.

        Code Samples

        Get 10 handles with recursive call.

        Iterable<HandleItem> result = directoryClient.getHandles(10, true);
System.out.printf("Get handles completed with handle id %s", result.iterator().next().handleId());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        maxResult - Optional maximum number of results will return per page
        recursive - Specifies operation should apply to the directory specified in the URI, its files, its subdirectories and their files.
        Returns:
        handles in the directory that satisfy the requirements

      • forceCloseHandles

        public java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer> forceCloseHandles(java.lang.String handleId,
                                                               boolean recursive)
        Closes a handle or handles opened on a directory or a file at the service. It is intended to be used alongside DirectoryClient.getHandles(Integer, boolean) . TODO: Will change the return type to how many handles have been closed. Implement one more API to force close all handles. TODO: @see Github Issue 4525

        Code Samples

        Force close handles with handles returned by get handles in recursive.

        Iterable<HandleItem> result = directoryClient.getHandles(10, true);
result.forEach(handleItem ->  {
    directoryClient.forceCloseHandles(handleItem.handleId(), true).forEach(numOfClosedHandles ->
        System.out.printf("Get handles completed with handle id %s", handleItem.handleId()));
});

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        handleId - Specifies the handle ID to be closed. Use an asterisk ('*') as a wildcard string to specify all handles.
        recursive - A boolean value that specifies if the operation should also apply to the files and subdirectories of the directory specified in the URI.
        Returns:
        The counts of number of handles closed.

      • createSubDirectory

        public Response<DirectoryClient> createSubDirectory(java.lang.String subDirectoryName)
        Creates a subdirectory under current directory with specific name and returns a response of DirectoryClient to interact with it.

        Code Samples

        Create the sub directory "subdir" 

        Response<DirectoryClient> response = directoryClient.createSubDirectory("subdir");
System.out.println("Complete creating the subdirectory with status code " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        subDirectoryName - Name of the subdirectory
        Returns:
        A response containing the subdirectory client and the status of creating the directory.
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the subdirectory has already existed, the parent directory does not exist or directory is an invalid resource name.

      • createSubDirectory

        public Response<DirectoryClient> createSubDirectory(java.lang.String subDirectoryName,
                                                    java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> metadata)
        Creates a subdirectory under current directory with specific name , metadata and returns a response of DirectoryClient to interact with it.

        Code Samples

        Create the subdirectory named "subdir", with metadata

        Response<DirectoryClient> response = directoryClient.createSubDirectory("subdir",
    Collections.singletonMap("directory", "metadata"));
System.out.printf("Creating the sub directory completed with status code %d", response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        subDirectoryName - Name of the subdirectory
        metadata - Optional metadata to associate with the subdirectory
        Returns:
        A response containing the subdirectory client and the status of creating the directory.
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the directory has already existed, the parent directory does not exist or subdirectory is an invalid resource name.

      • deleteSubDirectory

        public VoidResponse deleteSubDirectory(java.lang.String subDirectoryName)
        Deletes the subdirectory with specific name in this directory. The directory must be empty before it can be deleted.

        Code Samples

        Delete the subdirectory named "subdir"

        VoidResponse response = directoryClient.deleteSubDirectory("mysubdirectory");
System.out.println("Complete deleting the subdirectory with status code: " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        subDirectoryName - Name of the subdirectory
        Returns:
        A response that only contains headers and response status code
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the subdirectory doesn't exist, the parent directory does not exist or subdirectory name is an invalid resource name.

      • createFile

        public Response<FileClient> createFile(java.lang.String fileName,
                                       long maxSize)
        Creates a file in this directory with specific name, max number of results and returns a response of DirectoryInfo to interact with it.

        Code Samples

        Create 1k file with named "myFile"

        Response<FileClient> response = directoryClient.createFile("myfile", 1024);
System.out.println("Complete creating the file with status code: " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        fileName - Name of the file
        maxSize - Size of the file
        Returns:
        A response containing the FileClient and the status of creating the directory.
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the file has already existed, the parent directory does not exist or file name is an invalid resource name.

      • createFile

        public Response<FileClient> createFile(java.lang.String fileName,
                                       long maxSize,
                                       FileHTTPHeaders httpHeaders,
                                       java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> metadata)
        Creates a file in this directory with specific name and returns a response of DirectoryInfo to interact with it.

        Code Samples

        Create the file named "myFile"

        FileHTTPHeaders httpHeaders = new FileHTTPHeaders().fileContentType("text/plain");
Response<FileClient> response = directoryClient.createFile("myFile", 1024,
    httpHeaders, Collections.singletonMap("directory", "metadata"));
System.out.println("Complete creating the file with status code: " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        fileName - Name of the file
        maxSize - Max size of the file
        httpHeaders - the Http headers set to the file
        metadata - Optional name-value pairs associated with the file as metadata. Metadata names must adhere to the naming rules.
        Returns:
        A response containing the directory info and the status of creating the directory.
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the directory has already existed, the parent directory does not exist or file name is an invalid resource name.

      • deleteFile

        public VoidResponse deleteFile(java.lang.String fileName)
        Deletes the file with specific name in this directory.

        Code Samples

        Delete the file "filetest"

        VoidResponse response = directoryClient.deleteFile("myfile");
System.out.println("Complete deleting the file with status code: " + response.statusCode());

        For more information, see the Azure Docs.

        Parameters:
        fileName - Name of the file
        Returns:
        A response that only contains headers and response status code
        Throws:
        StorageErrorException - If the directory doesn't exist or the file doesn't exist or file name is an invalid resource name.

      • getShareSnapshotId

        public java.lang.String getShareSnapshotId()
        Get snapshot id which attached to DirectoryClient. Return null if no snapshot id attached.

        Code Samples

        Get the share snapshot id. 

        OffsetDateTime currentTime = OffsetDateTime.of(LocalDateTime.now(), ZoneOffset.UTC);
DirectoryClient directoryClient = new DirectoryClientBuilder()
    .endpoint("https://${accountName}.file.core.windows.net")
    .credential(SASTokenCredential.fromQuery("${SASToken}"))
    .shareName("myshare")
    .directoryPath("mydirectory")
    .snapshot(currentTime.toString())
    .buildClient();
directoryClient.getShareSnapshotId();
        Returns:
        The snapshot id which is a unique DateTime value that identifies the share snapshot to its base share.
